questions.text: Which system is widely used for reporting thyroid cytopathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bethesda System

 

Explanation:

 

  • The Bethesda System for Reporting Thyroid Cytopathology (TBSRTC) is a standardised reporting system designed to classify thyroid Fine-Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) biopsy results.
  • The system includes six diagnostic categories, ranging from non-diagnostic/unsatisfactory to malignant.

 

The Bethesda System for Reporting Thyroid Cytopathology

 

Diagnostic category

Risk of malignancy (%)

Usual management

Non-diagnostic

5-20

Repeat FNAC with ultrasound guidance

Benign

2-7

Clinical and sonographic follow-up

Atypia of undetermined significance

13-30

Repeat FNAC, molecular testing, diagnostic lobectomy, or surveillance

Follicular neoplasm

23-34

Molecular testing, diagnostic lobectomy

Suspicious for malignancy

67-83

Molecular testing, lobectomy, or near-total thyroidectomy

Malignant

97-100

Lobectomy or near-total thyroidectomy

 

The Bethesda system is also used to report cervical cytology.


 

TIRADS (Thyroid Imaging Reporting and Data System) (Option A) is a classification system for reporting thyroid ultrasound findings, not cytopathology.

 

Gleason’s System (Option B) is used to grade prostate cancer based on histological patterns.

 

Duke Classification (Option D) is a system for staging colorectal cancer.

questions.text:
You are examining a high-resolution microscopic image of thyroid tissue. Which of the following depicts cells responsible for the secretion of calcitonin?

 



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) B

 

Explanation:

Parafollicular cells responsible for calcitonin secretion are indicated by ‘B’ in the given image.

 

  • C-cells secrete the hormone calcitonin (Hypocalcemic Hormone).
  • C-cells (Parafollicular Cells) cells are columnar with basally located nuclei.

 

Follicular Cells (Option A) have a round nucleus and basophilic cytoplasm. Their function is to synthesize thyroid hormones.

 

Colloid (Option C) is a gel-like substance that appears pinkish and homogeneous in the follicles and serves as a reservoir for thyroid hormones.

 

Stromal Cells (Option D) fill up spaces between the follicles and connective tissue, capillaries, and lymphatics.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female presents with fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance. On physical examination, she has diffuse goitre and dry skin. Histopathological examination shows lymphoid infiltration, atrophic thyroid follicles lined in many areas by epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
The above scenario and HPE findings suggest a diagnosis of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

  • It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas.
  • It is characterised by painless enlargement of the thyroid, commonly in middle-aged women. The enlargement of the gland is generally symmetric and diffuse.
  • In histopathology, there is extensive lymphocytic infiltration with well-developed germinal centres. The thyroid follicles are atrophic and are lined in many areas by epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm, termed Hürthle cells.
  • Hürthle cells represent a metaplastic response of the normally low cuboidal follicular epithelium to chronic injury.

 

The thyroid parenchyma contains a dense lymphocytic infiltrate with germinal centres.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies are elevated in a patient of Hashimoto's thyroiditis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies (Anti-TPO)

 

Explanation:

  • In Hashimoto's thyroiditis, the immune system mistakenly targets the thyroid gland, leading to chronic inflammation and damage. Antibodies play a crucial role in this process.
  1. Anti-Thyroid Peroxidase (TPO) Antibodies: Target an enzyme called thyroid peroxidase, which helps synthesise thyroid hormones. They are a hallmark of Hashimoto's thyroiditis and are frequently elevated in affected individuals.
  2. Anti-Thyroglobulin(Tg) Antibodies: Thyroglobulin is a protein involved in thyroid hormone production. Antibodies against thyroglobulin can disrupt hormone synthesis and contribute to thyroid gland damage.

 

Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) are found in Graves' disease. (Option A)
 

Anti-thyroid stimulating hormone receptor antibodies (Anti-TSHR): These antibodies are typically associated with autoimmune thyroid diseases such as Graves' disease. (Option C)

questions.text:
A 29-year-old lady has been experiencing loss of appetite, profuse sweating, and palpitations for the past three months. Laboratory tests conclude increased T3 and T4 levels with decreased TSH levels. A representative HPE of this condition is shown below. The most common antibodies in this condition target which of the following?

 



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
The HPE image shows features of Grave’s disease most commonly as Long-acting thyroid stimulator antibodies that target the TSH receptor.

 

The HPE image shows the microscopic finding of Graves disease, characterised by

  1. Follicles are lined by hyperplastic, enlarged epithelial cells that project into the lumens of the follicles, forming papillary projections. These are called Pseudopapillae (vs true papillae containing a fibrovascular core).
  2. These cells actively resorb the colloid in the centres of the follicles, resulting in the scalloped appearance of the colloid's edges.

 

Antibodies in Graves disease: TSI - Thyroid stimulating immunoglobulin

or LATS - Long-acting thyroid stimulator. These antibodies attach to the TSH receptor and stimulate them, leading to excessive release of T3 and T4.

  • This results in hyperthyroidism

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office due to progressively worsening eye irritation and double vision over the last two months. She also reports unintentional weight loss, mood swings, diarrhoea, and palpitations. Physical examination shows tachycardia and bilateral proptosis. What is the pathophysiology causing proptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Increased activity of orbital fibroblasts

 

Explanation:

  • This patient with hyperthyroidism (weight loss, palpitations, tachycardia) and significant ophthalmopathy (proptosis, diplopia) has Graves disease with ophthalmopathy, which is due to increased activity of orbital fibroblasts.
  • Graves disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by thyrotropin receptor antibodies that activate the TSH receptor.
  • The TSH receptor is also on fibroblasts, adipocytes, and other cell types.

 

Triad in Graves:

  1. Hyperthyroidism
  2. Proptosis
  3. Pretibial myxoedema- infiltrative dermopathy due to thickening of the dermis due to deposition of glycosaminoglycans and lymphocyte infiltration

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the gross morphology of Riedel’s thyroiditis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Stony and hard consistency.

 

Explanation:

  • Riedel's Thyroiditis belongs to an IgG4-related disease that causes extensive fibrosis.
  • Fibrosis causes the thyroid to become stony and hard.
  • It also attaches the thyroid to the adjacent tissues, muscles, and vessels implying the mass is fixed and does not move with deglutition.
  • So it behaves like/mimics a cancer.

 

Other IgG4-related diseases include:

  1. Mikulicz syndrome- Affects salivary and lacrimal gland
  2. Kuttner syndrome- Sclerosis of the submandibular gland
  3. Ormond disease- Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis
  4. Angiocentric fibrosis- Involves nasal cavity

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis?

choices.text: Usually presents as a painful enlargement of the thyroid

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Usually presents as a painful enlargement of the thyroid

 

Explanation:

 

  • Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis is typically a painless enlargement of the thyroid.
  • Usually presents postpartum in 5% of women and is presumed to have an autoimmune aetiology.
  • The self-limiting condition does not usually require treatment
  • Characterised by lymphocytic inflammation in the thyroid.

questions.text: What is the finding in the histopathological examination of a biopsy specimen from a patient with De Quervain Thyroiditis?

choices.text: Extensive stromal fibrosis extending beyond the thyroid capsule
Mononuclear infiltration with well-developed germinal centres
Mixed cellular infiltration with occasional multinucleated giant cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mixed cellular infiltration with occasional multinucleated giant cells

 

Explanation:

Painful enlargement of the thyroid gland following a viral infection such as mumps, is suggestive of de Quervain thyroiditis.

The microscopic findings include:

  • Large multinucleated giant cells
  • Giant cells with engulfed colloid
  • Mixed cellular infiltration

questions.text:
A 55-year-old patient presents with a solitary thyroid nodule. The patient also reports difficulty swallowing, with no complaints of weight loss, fatigue, or heat intolerance. An excisional biopsy reveals >75% of the following characteristic cells. Which genetic mutation is most commonly associated with this type of thyroid tumour?

 



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) RAS

 

Explanation:

The above image shows cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and small regular nuclei, suggesting Hurthle cells. The presence of >75% of these cells indicates a Hurthle cell tumour, a rare thyroid neoplasm of follicular cell origin associated with RAS mutation.

  • Hurthle cell adenomas are variants of follicular adenoma, and the presence of more than 75% of Hurthle cells is a key diagnostic feature.

Hürthle cell (oxyphil) adenoma comprises cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and small regular nuclei.
 

Thyroid Malignancy

Mutations/Genetic Alterations

Follicular Thyroid Adenoma

(Benign Condition)
  • RAS

Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC)
  • BRAF V600E
  • RET/PTC rearrangements

Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma (FTC)
  • RAS
  • PAX8-PPARγ rearrangements
  • PIK3CA

Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC)
  • RET

Anaplastic Thyroid Carcinoma (ATC)
  • TP53

questions.text:
Match each type of thyroid tumour with its most commonly associated risk factor:

 


	
		
			
			Thyroid Carcinoma
			
			
			Risk Factors:
			
		
		
			
			1. Papillary thyroid carcinoma
			
			
			A. Iodine deficiency
			
		
		
			
			2. Follicular thyroid carcinoma
			
			
			B. RET proto-oncogene mutations
			
		
		
			
			3. Medullary thyroid carcinoma
			
			
			C. Radiation exposure
			
		
		
			
			4. Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma
			
			
			D. History of a well-differentiated

			follicular neoplasm
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A)1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-D

Explanation:

 

Thyroid Cancer Type

Risk Factors

Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma
  • Radiation exposure (especially in childhood)
  • Family history of thyroid cancer
  • Hashimoto thyroiditis
  • Thyroglossal cyst

Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Long-standing Goiter.

Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma
  • RET proto-oncogene mutations.
  • Family history (e.g., MEN2 syndrome)

Anaplastic Thyroid Carcinoma
  • Older age
  • ¼ th of patients have a past history of a well-differentiated follicular neoplasm
  • Previous radiation exposure

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with a nodule in the anterior neck and lymphadenopathy. The tumour is found to have spread to the lymphatics. Histopathological examination shows characteristic findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Papillary thyroid carcinoma

 

Explanation:

The above features and HPE showing psammoma bodies, nuclear grooves, and "Orphan Annie eye" nuclei are indicative of papillary thyroid carcinoma.

 

  • This is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is characterised by lymphatic spread.
  • It often presents with a nodule in the anterior neck and lymphadenopathy.
  • Associated with BRAF mutations and RET-PTC fusion

 

HPE shows:

  1. True papillae- Fingerlike projections with fibrovascular core.
  2. Orphan Annie eye nuclei - Optically clear nucleus produced due to artefact.
  3. Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions (INCI).
  4. Nuclear groove or coffee bean nucleus.
  5. Presence of psammoma bodies- Dystrophic calcifications
  • It has the best prognosis among thyroid malignancies

 

 

Follicular thyroid carcinoma (Option A):Typically spreads haematogenously (to bone, lungs), not via lymphatics. Requires capsular and vascular invasion for diagnosis.

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (Option B): Arises from parafollicular (C) cells, associated with calcitonin production and sometimes MEN syndromes. Histology shows amyloid stroma, not papillary features.

Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma (Option D): A very aggressive and undifferentiated tumour, usually in elderly, presents with rapid growth and poor prognosis. Histology shows pleomorphic, spindle cells, not papillary patterns.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common feature of follicular carcinoma of thyroid?

choices.text: FNAC is not helpful in diagnosis

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Commonly spreads by lymphatic route

 

Explanation:

Spread by lymphatic route is not a common feature of follicular carcinoma as they commonly spread by hematogenous route.

 

  • Follicular carcinoma of thyroid is the second common malignancy of thyroid following papillary Ca.
  • They are commonly associated with K-RAS mutation
  • Capsular and vascular invasion on biopsy is a diagnostic feature of follicular carcinoma.
  • FNAC is not helpful in diagnosis of follicular carcinomas.
  • Regional lymph nodes are typically not involved and hematogenous spread to bone,
  • lungs and liver are more common.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a painless lump on the front of the neck, bone pain, fatigue, and episodes of flushed skin. Genetic studies reveal a mutation in the RET gene. Which type of amyloid is typically deposited in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A-CAL

 

Explanation:

The given scenario and mutation are associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, which has amyloid deposition derived from calcitonin, known as A-CAL.

 

  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is a neuroendocrine tumour arising from parafollicular C cells.
  • They secrete calcitonin, which regulates calcium levels and is also a marker for diagnosis and postoperative follow-up. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a marker in which calcitonin is negative.
  • They can be sporadic or associated with familial syndromes like MEN 2.
  • Both have associated RET mutations.
  • Sporadic tumours usually present with solitary nodules whereas familial ones are characterised by bilaterality and multicentricity, and can have features of other associated tumours.
  • A biopsy would show amyloid deposits (Acal) derived from calcitonin polypeptides.


 

A-β (Option A): It is associated with Alzheimer's disease.

 

A-L (Option C): Is associated with primary amyloidosis and multiple myeloma, derived from immunoglobulin light chains.

 

A-TTR (Option D): It is associated with transthyretin and is seen in conditions like familial amyloid polyneuropathy and senile systemic amyloidosis.
